title: Data Visualisation in R
text:
Data Visualisation in R helps you transform complex datasets into clear, compelling, and insightful stories.


Modern life produces massive amounts of data, from medical records and government reports to consumer behaviour and scientific experiments. These raw data are often impossible to interpret directly. Effective visualisation is what makes patterns, relationships, and insights easy to grasp. It is also one of the most in-demand skills in both academia and industry.



Designing good visualisations isn’t just about producing a chart. It requires practice in matching the right data to the right visualisation, choosing what to emphasise, and making design choices that enhance clarity rather than confuse.



You’ll find that creating visualisations can be highly engaging and satisfying. There is an immediate reward when a messy dataset suddenly becomes a meaningful picture. You’ll also discover creative opportunities—choosing colours, layouts, and styles that make your work both clear and attractive. By the end of the course you’ll be able to build professional-quality figures, dashboards, and even interactive apps that you can proudly showcase.
The time and effort you put into learning Data Visualisation in R WILL reward you no matter how you evaluate yourself relative to others. You will be able to:

Explore and understand datasets by visualising distributions, relationships, and trends.
Design clear and comprehensible visualisations that avoid common pitfalls.
Communicate findings to diverse audiences through compelling storytelling.
Build interactive dashboards that combine multiple visualisations.
Apply these skills across your degree and in a wide range of careers.

title: Independent Study to Consolidate
text:
If you have just opened RStudio you will want to load the tidyverse, RColorBrewer, viridis and patchwork packages.

 Save this file in your week-6 folder:

App engagement dataset: app_engagement.csv

Customer ops dataset: customer_ops.csv


 Add the following code to your R script and run:

engagement <- read_csv("app_engagement.csv")
ops <- read_csv("customer_ops.csv")


head(engagement)

# A tibble: 6 × 5
  user_id user_segment device_type acquisition_channel product_engagement
    <dbl> <fct>        <fct>       <chr>                            <dbl>
1       1 MidCareer    Mobile      Organic                           55.8
2       2 EarlyCareer  Desktop     Organic                           89.9
3       3 Students     Desktop     Organic                           40.6
4       4 Senior       Mobile      Organic                           48.7
5       5 MidCareer    Mobile      Ads                               51.1
6       6 Students     Mobile      Referral                          79.1

head(ops)

# A tibble: 6 × 6
  employee_id job_role          training_hours client_contacts task_switch_hours
  <chr>       <fct>                      <dbl>           <dbl>             <dbl>
1 E0001       account_manager              6.1            9.47               9  
2 E0002       support_engineer             6.1            6.41               5.9
3 E0003       implement_specia…            7              4.27               5  
4 E0004       account_manager              5.7            6.72               8.7
5 E0005       support_engineer             6.4            9.33               7  
6 E0006       account_manager              6.6            7.62               6.2
# ℹ 1 more variable: performance_index <dbl>



Some of the factors in the dataset have natural orders that we should enforce.
 Use mutate and factor to reorder the levels of the following factors:
engagement dataset:


user_segment: levels = Students, EarlyCareer, MidCareer, Senior

device_type: levels = Desktop, Mobile

ops dataset:


job_role: levels = support_engineer, implement_specialist, account_manager


Using engagement, create a bar plot of product_engagement by user_segment, with points for individual values.
 Use color, labels, and themes to polish the appearance of the plot. The plot below is just an example to illustrate an approach you could take (with your own choice of labels).









Compute group centers and place labels directly on the plot.
 Create a tibble of user_segment means, then label them with geom_label(). Hide redundant legends.









Practice using facets to compare groups and combining plots to compare patterns.
Note: The plots below are just an example of what to aim for - your plots can look different.
 Switch to the ops dataset and illustrate two relationships: training_hours vs performance_index and (2) task_switch_hours vs performance_index. Improve these plots by:

Adding nicely formatted labels to the job_role factor (modify the job_role factor using mutate and factor)
Adding trend lines
Faceting by job_role to compare patterns across job_role groups
Choosing informative titles and axis labels
Combining the plots using patchwork

title: Independent Study to Consolidate
text:
Exercise 1: Satisfaction over time
Let’s start out by looking at changes in satisfaction over time.
 Generate a plot that shows how patient_satisfaction changes over year.
Reflect: Do you see satisfaction trending up, down, or flat across years?

title: Independent Study to Consolidate
text:
Exercise 2: Policy comparison
Now let’s see how the changes differ across the two policies.
 Use different-colored lines and ribbons to show how the change in patient_satisfaction over year differs across policies.
Reflect: Do the policies diverge or converge over the years?

title: Independent Study to Consolidate
text:
Exercise 3: Faceting by seniority
Now let’s see how differences between policies in trends over time differ across agents with different levels of seniority.
First, we’ll want to order the levels of the seniority variable from least to most seniority.
 Use mutate to specify the order of the seniority factor levels as junior, mid, senior.
 Use facets to contrast the changes in patient_satisfaction over years for the different policies across levels of seniority.
Reflect: Does the effect of policy differ across junior, mid, and senior agents?

title: Independent Study to Consolidate
text:
Exercise 4: Parse time values
The mmss column stores durations like "06:30.7" or "116:08.0" as character strings.
 Convert mmss into a time variable called mmss_period using ms(), then convert mmss_period into an h:m:s-format time variable using hms::hms().
Reflect: Why did we import mmss as character instead of letting read_csv guess a time type? What goes wrong for strings like "116:08.0"?

title: Independent Study to Consolidate
text:
Exercise 5: Compare all metrics
The dataset has three time metrics (first_response, handle_time, resolution_time) on very different scales.
Let’s visualize trends in the three metrics in different panels.
 Plot the changes in mmss_hms over year with separate lines for policy and separate facets for metric. Free up the y-axis ranges as needed.
Reflect: Why is scales = "free_y" helpful here? What happens without it?

title: Practical
text:
In this practical you’ll start from basic plots and polish them using the strategies from Seminar 7:

Clear, reader-friendly labels with labs()

Smarter scales with scale_*_* (breaks, labels, limits, discrete & continuous colors)
Visual polish with theme()


Annotations and direct labels (geom_text() / geom_label())

Faceting (facet_wrap, facet_grid) and patchwork for multi-panel figures

Practicals are not a test. It is expected that you often don’t know how to start, make a lot of mistakes and need help. It is expected that you are familiar with independent study content before the workshop. However, you need not remember or understand every detail as the workshop should build and consolidate your understanding. Tips

don’t worry about making mistakes
don’t let what you can not do interfere with what you can do
discussing code with your neighbours will help
look things up in the independent study material
look things up in your own code from earlier workshops
there are no stupid questions







Key



These four symbols are used at the beginning of each instruction so you know where to carry out the instruction.
 Something you need to do on your computer. It may be opening programs or documents or locating a file.
 Something you should do in RStudio. It will often be typing a command or using the menus but might also be creating folders, locating or moving files.
 Something you should do in your browser on the internet. It may be searching for information, going to the VLE or downloading a file.
 A question for you to think about and answer. Record your answers in your script for future reference.

title: Practical
text:
Load packages
We’ll be using some additional packages for today’s exercises (and they will be useful for you in the future).
 Load the packages below. If you get a message saying that the package does not exist, use install.packages("name of package") to install and then try loading again.

library(viridis)   # viridis palettes
library(RColorBrewer) # brewer palettes
library(patchwork) # combine plots

title: Practical
text:
Exercise 1: Labels that communicate
We’ll start with a simple scatterplot of sleep vs wellbeing.
 Start with this base plot:

ggplot(wellbeing, aes(x = sleep_hours, y = wellbeing_index)) +
  geom_point()







 Improve the plot:

Use labs() to add a title and clearly label the axes (e.g., “Sleep (avg hours/night)”, “Wellbeing Index (0–100)”)
Make tick marks helpful: use coord_cartesian and set breaks for scale_*_continuous so that: (A) the x-axis ranges from 4 to 10 with tick marks every 1 hour, and (B) the y-axis ranges from 30 to 90 with tick marks every 15 pints.

Improve baseline readability via built-in themes like theme_bw() and manual adjustments with theme() (e.g., font size, gridlines).









 In one sentence: What is the main take-home from this scatter?

title: Practical
section: Exercise 2: Discrete color with a legend that helps
text:
Exercise 2: Discrete color with a legend that helps
Color points by participant_group and make the legend useful.
 Color the points in the plot from Exercise 1 by participant_group

ggplot(wellbeing, aes(x = sleep_hours, y = wellbeing_index)) +
  geom_point(aes(color = participant_group))







 Improve the use and labelling of color:

Use labs() to rename the legend title. Remember that any aes() you set is available to labs()

Use either viridis (discrete) scale_color_viridis_d() or a brewer qualitative palette (e.g., scale_color_brewer(palette = "Set2")).

Adjust legend placement with theme(legend.position = "top") (or another purposeful spot).

 Which palette did you choose and why?

title: Practical
section: Exercise 3: Explore available color palettes and tools
text:
Exercise 3: Explore available color palettes and tools
We touched upon the brewer and viridis palettes. However, these are just some of the options. Many people have developed color palettes you can use in R, and you can create your own.
 Look at the many palette options on this website
 Google “color picker”. You should see a tool that allows you to pick colors and provides ways to specify the color you picked. For example, it provides the HEX reference (e.g., “#6a788f”), which you can use to label colors in ggplots (e.g., geom_point(color = "#6a788f")).

title: Practical
section: Exercise 4: Discrete axes & readable bar summaries
text:
Exercise 4: Discrete axes & readable bar summaries
Make a bar plt of wellbeing by participant_group
 Start with this base plot:

ggplot(wellbeing, aes(x = participant_group, y = wellbeing_index)) +
  stat_summary(aes(fill = participant_group), fun = "mean", geom = "bar")







 Improve the base plot by doing the following:

Use labs() for a clear title and axis titles
Rename x-axis group labels with scale_x_discrete(labels = c(...)), e.g., to be “Employed”, “Retired” and “Student”
Use brewer or discrete viridis palette to alter the fill colors
Note that the legend is redundant with the x-axis. Use theme() to remove the legend by setting its position as none. In addition, improve the overall polish of the plot using built in themes and/or adding further adjustments within theme()

title: Practical
text:
Exercise 5: Direct labels
Switch to the therapy dataset and explore loneliness vs wellbeing, colored by support_level
 Starter plot:

ggplot(therapy, aes(x = loneliness_score, y = wellbeing_score)) +
  geom_point(aes(color = support_level))







Replace legend referencing with direct labels near group centers.
 Create a tibble that computes each group’s center using group_by and summarise. Store the tibble, e.g., as an object called centers.


# A tibble: 3 × 3
  support_level loneliness_center wellbeing_center
  <chr>                     <dbl>            <dbl>
1 High                       21.0             86.2
2 Low                        59.2             48.9
3 Medium                     42.2             67.3


 Use geom_label to use the tibble to label the groups. Note that because we are now using labels to identify the groups, using a legend to identify them would be redundant. Therefore, set show.legend to FALSE for both geom_point and geom_label.








 Did direct labels make the plot faster to understand? Can you think of cases in which direct labels would make the plot harder to understand?

title: Practical
section: Exercise 6: Faceting to compare groups without clutter
text:
Exercise 6: Faceting to compare groups without clutter
Explore how the loneliness vs wellbeing relation differs by group.
 Reorder the levels of the support_level factor using mutate and factor so that the order is: Low, Medium, High
 Return to this basic scatterplot:

ggplot(therapy, aes(x = loneliness_score, y = wellbeing_score)) +
  geom_point()







 Add trendlines and split plot into facets to compare trends across groups

Add a geom_smooth line to the code to shows the linear regression line for the relationship between sleep_hours and wellbeing_index for each participant_group.
Use facet_wrap to create separate facets for each participant_group

Use built-in themes and theme() to remove the gray background from the plots and facet titles

title: Practical
text:
Exercise 7: Continuous color scale (viridis) and
Switch to examining the loneliness vs wellbeing relationship by sleep_quality (continuous)
 Starter plot:

ggplot(therapy, aes(x = loneliness_score, y = wellbeing_score)) +
  geom_point()







 Color by sleep_quality and customize:

Within geom_point, color the points based on sleep_quality

Customize the colors used for sleep_quality using a viridis scale. Within this line:

Use the option argument to choose one of the non-default color scales
Set the name of the legend to something more readable
Choose breaks that reduce legend clutter


Use labs() to improve the axis labels
Use theme() to place the legend in a different position

title: Practical
section: Exercise 8: Facet grid for compact subgroup comparisons
text:
Exercise 8: Facet grid for compact subgroup comparisons
 Compare the pattern in Exercise 7 by sex and therapy:

Use facet_grid to create facets with separate rows for sex and separate columns for therapy. Include a labeller to add a “Sex:” prefix to the row labels and a “Therapy:” prefix to the column labels.
Use built-in themes and theme() to customize the appearance of the plot, including removing the gray background from the plot and facet titles









 Do the facets reveal effects of sex and/or therapy?
 Look at the documentation for the labeller function using ?labeller to see the many ways to customise facet_wrap and facet_grid labels

title: Practical
section: Exercise 9: Using patchwork to make tidy multi-panel figures
text:
Exercise 9: Using patchwork to make tidy multi-panel figures
Create two polished plots and combine them with patchwork.
 Use or modify any two of your improved plots from the preceding exercises that provide different insights into the same dataset (either wellbeing or therapy) and combine them with patchwork - Choose whether to align plots horizontally or vertically - Add plot_annotation() to auto-label panels A, B - Ensure consistent style (font size, theme tweaks) across panels
 What patterns does each figure highlight, and how does combining them provide complementary insights into the data?

Why line graphs?
mean satisfaction per year


Could use bar graph, but not great for trends - don’t capture continuous nature of change, always start at 0

text:
Why line graphs?
mean satisfaction per year


Especially for comparing trends across multiple groups
crumbs: Week 6: Time Series and Line Plots

title: Week 6 Seminar: Time Series and Line Graphs
text:
Today

Line graphs for time series data
Multiple groups and avoiding “spaghetti plots”

Working with dates and times using lubridate and hms
Other uses of line graphs


As we’ll see, lines are better
crumbs: Week 6: Time Series and Line Plots

title: Week 6 Seminar: Time Series and Line Graphs
text:
Line Graph: Basic
mean satisfaction per year

ggplot(telehealth, aes(x = year, y = patient_satisfaction)) +
  stat_summary(fun = "mean", geom = "line") #< summary to aggregate



We use stat_summary(fun = "mean", geom = "line") to draw a line of yearly averages.
If we had just one patient_satisfaction value per year, we wouldn’t need to aggregate and would use geom_line.
crumbs: Week 6: Time Series and Line Plots

title: Week 6 Seminar: Time Series and Line Graphs
text:
Line Graph: Add uncertainty
line + ribbon

ggplot(telehealth, aes(x = year, y = patient_satisfaction)) +
  stat_summary(fun = "mean", geom = "line") +
  stat_summary(fun.data = "mean_se", geom = "ribbon", alpha = 0.2)
crumbs: Week 6: Time Series and Line Plots

title: Week 6 Seminar: Time Series and Line Graphs
text:
Line Graph: Add uncertainty
line + pointrange

ggplot(telehealth, aes(x = year, y = patient_satisfaction)) +
  stat_summary(fun = "mean", geom = "line") +
  stat_summary(fun.data = "mean_se", geom = "pointrange")
crumbs: Week 6: Time Series and Line Plots

title: Week 6 Seminar: Time Series and Line Graphs
text:

Line graphs for time series data

Working with dates and times using lubridate and hms

title: Week 6 Seminar: Time Series and Line Graphs
text:
Multiple groups
compare policies over time

ggplot(telehealth, aes(x = year, y = patient_satisfaction)) +
  stat_summary(aes(color = policy),  #< note hidden "group" aes()
               fun = "mean", geom = "line") +
  stat_summary(aes(fill = policy),   #< note hidden "group" aes()
               fun.data = "mean_se", geom = "ribbon", alpha = 0.2)
crumbs: Week 6: Time Series and Line Plots

title: Week 6 Seminar: Time Series and Line Graphs
text:
Multiple groups: Spaghetti plots
compare seniority over time

ggplot(telehealth, aes(x = year, y = patient_satisfaction)) +
  stat_summary(aes(color = seniority), 
               fun = "mean", geom = "line") +
  stat_summary(aes(fill = seniority), 
               fun.data = "mean_se", geom = "ribbon", alpha = 0.2)
crumbs: Week 6: Time Series and Line Plots

title: Week 6 Seminar: Time Series and Line Graphs
text:
Reducing spaghetti plots
faceting

ggplot(telehealth, aes(x = year, y = patient_satisfaction)) +
  facet_wrap(~seniority) + 
  stat_summary(fun = "mean", geom = "line", color = "blue") +
  stat_summary(fun.data = "mean_se", geom = "ribbon", alpha = 0.2)
crumbs: Week 6: Time Series and Line Plots

title: Week 6 Seminar: Time Series and Line Graphs
text:
Reducing spaghetti plots
faceting: nrow

ggplot(telehealth, aes(x = year, y = patient_satisfaction)) +
  facet_wrap(~seniority, nrow = 3) + #< override default using nrow
  stat_summary(fun = "mean", geom = "line", color = "blue") +
  stat_summary(fun.data = "mean_se", geom = "ribbon", alpha = 0.2)
crumbs: Week 6: Time Series and Line Plots

title: Week 6 Seminar: Time Series and Line Graphs
text:
Reducing spaghetti plots
highlighting

telehealth %>%
  mutate(highlight = ifelse(seniority == "senior", "highlight", "standard")) %>%
  ggplot(aes(x = year, y = patient_satisfaction)) +
  stat_summary(aes(group = seniority, color = highlight),
               fun = "mean", geom = "line") +
  stat_summary(aes(group = seniority, fill = highlight), 
               fun.data = "mean_se", geom = "ribbon", alpha = 0.2) +
  scale_color_manual(values = c("blue", "gray", "gray")) +

Working with times
parse mmss with lubridate::ms() and hms::hms()

telehealth <- telehealth %>%

title: Overview
text:
This week you will learn how to use lines to visualize changes over time. We will cover basic line graphs, emphasizing differences in trends between groups, and working with date and time variables. Note that the preparation for this week includes a DataCamp course that will go more in depth into date and time variables.

Learning objectives
The successful student will be able to:

generate line graphs to show trends over time
use color, facets, and highlights to emphasize differences in trends between categorical groups
manipulate date and time variables for clear visualization
crumbs: Week 6: Time Series and Line Plots

title: Practical
text:
In this practical you will read in two datasets and create plots that show relationships between continuous variables, add trend lines, explore differences across categorical groups, and practice joining related datasets.

Practicals are not a test. It is expected that you often don’t know how to start, make a lot of mistakes and need help. It is expected that you are familiar with independent study content before the workshop. However, you need not remember or understand every detail as the workshop should build and consolidate your understanding. Tips

don’t worry about making mistakes
don’t let what you can not do interfere with what you can do
discussing code with your neighbours will help
look things up in the independent study material
look things up in your own code from earlier workshops
there are no stupid questions







Key



These four symbols are used at the beginning of each instruction so you know where to carry out the instruction.
 Something you need to do on your computer. It may be opening programs or documents or locating a file.
 Something you should do in RStudio. It will often be typing a command or using the menus but might also be creating folders, locating or moving files.
 Something you should do in your browser on the internet. It may be searching for information, going to the VLE or downloading a file.
 A question for you to think about and answer. Record your answers in your script for future reference.

title: Practical
text:
Today’s data
We’ll use two related CSVs about social media and wellbeing. The primary dataset has one row per participant with three continuous variables and one categorical moderator. The secondary dataset has one row per participant with two additional variables and a 90‑day follow‑up score.

Primary (wellbeing_primary.csv):


participant_id (identifier)

participant_group (Student, Employed, Retired)

sleep_hours (hours per night)

social_hours (hours of social media per week)

wellbeing_index (0–100)


Secondary (wellbeing_secondary.csv):


participant_id (identifier)

notifications_on (TRUE/FALSE)

in_person_hours (hours per week of in-person socialising)

wellbeing_90d (0–100 follow-up)



Load the data
 Save this file in your week-5 folder:

Wellbeing primary: wellbeing_primary.csv

Wellbeing secondary: wellbeing_secondary.csv


 Add the following code to your R script and run:

well_p <- read_csv("wellbeing_primary.csv")
well_s <- read_csv("wellbeing_secondary.csv")

title: Practical
text:
Look at the data
 Examine the variables and first few rows of the well_p and well_s objects using head().

head(well_p)

# A tibble: 6 × 5
  participant_id participant_group sleep_hours social_hours wellbeing_index
  <chr>          <chr>                   <dbl>        <dbl>           <dbl>
1 P0001          student                   8.3          5.5            80.6
2 P0002          student                   7.3         13              51  
3 P0003          employed                  7.4          2.6            64.8
4 P0004          student                   6.1          4.1            61.8
5 P0005          student                   9.8          1.5            83.2
6 P0006          student                   7.9          4.6            62.4

head(well_s)

# A tibble: 6 × 4
  participant_id notifications_on in_person_hours wellbeing_90d
  <chr>          <lgl>                      <dbl>         <dbl>
1 P0001          FALSE                        7.3          65.8
2 P0002          FALSE                        8.2          41.4
3 P0003          TRUE                         5.5          57.5
4 P0004          TRUE                         5.7          31.5
5 P0005          TRUE                         8.9          70.5
6 P0006          FALSE                        9.9          45.6


See that each column is a variable (e.g., social_hours), and each row is a participant.

title: Practical
text:
Reorder the values of participant_group

As a reminder, sometimes categorical variables have a natural order that we want to specify.
In this dataset, participant_group is a factor with a natural order from junior to senior: student, employed, retired.
 Reorder the levels of user_segement.

well_p <- well_p %>%
  mutate(participant_group = factor(participant_group, levels = c("student", "employed", "retired")))

title: Practical
text:
Exercise 1: Basic scatterplot
 Plot sleep_hours (x) vs wellbeing_index (y).








 Describe the overall pattern. Is it roughly positive, negative, or flat?
 Improve readability by setting transparency of points using alpha.

title: Practical
text:
Exercise 2: Improve Readability: Jitter
Suppose many x-values were identical and would therefore overlap in the plot.
 Add a variable that rounds hours to the nearest whole number

well_p <- well_p %>%
  mutate(sleep_hours_round = round(sleep_hours, 0))

 Try generating a basic scatterplot of sleep_hours_round (x) vs wellbeing_index (y).








See how overlap makes the plot difficult to read.
 Add jitter to geom_point() using position = position_jitter(). Note that within position_jitter(), you can set the width and height. If you leave them blank, default values will be used. However, these default values are probably not ideal. Consider: do you really want to jitter both width and height? If you only want to jitter one, set the value of the other to 0. For the one you do want to jitter, choose a value that makes the plot more clear and readable.

title: Practical
text:
Exercise 3: Add a trend line
Add a linear model line to emphasise the relationship.
 Return to plotting sleep_hours versus wellbeing_index. Fit a straight line with geom_smooth(method = "lm").








 What does the slope suggest about the relationship between sleep and wellbeing?

title: Practical
section: Exercise 4: Relationships can differ by group
text:
Exercise 4: Relationships can differ by group
Now lets look at the relationship between social media use (social_hours) and wellbeing (wellbeing_index).
This relationship may differ by participant_group. We can colour by group and draw group‑specific lines.
 Plot social_hours vs wellbeing_index, coloured by participant_group with separate trend lines.








 Compare slopes across groups. Which group shows the strongest negative association between social media use and wellbeing? Which shows the weakest?

title: Practical
text:
Exercise 5: Facet by group
Sometimes separate panels are easier to compare than separate colors in one panel.
 Facet panels by participant_group and add a line per facet.








 Why does faceting improve readability here?
Note that it looks like different participant groups have different ranges of social_hours. By default, facet_wrap() uses the same range across all panels.
It is possible to alter facet_wrap() to use different ranges for the x-axis, y-axis or both across panels.
 Within facet_wrap(), add scales = "free_x". Note how the ranges of the x-axis now differ across panels.

title: Practical
section: Exercise 6: Join the primary and secondary datasets
text:
Exercise 6: Join the primary and secondary datasets
The secondary dataset, well_s, contains variables that give us additional information about the participants.
 Use left_join to combine well_s and well_p by participant_id. Name the joined dataset well_join.
 Look at the joined dataset.

head(well_join)

# A tibble: 6 × 9
  participant_id notifications_on in_person_hours wellbeing_90d
  <chr>          <lgl>                      <dbl>         <dbl>
1 P0001          FALSE                        7.3          65.8
2 P0002          FALSE                        8.2          41.4
3 P0003          TRUE                         5.5          57.5
4 P0004          TRUE                         5.7          31.5
5 P0005          TRUE                         8.9          70.5
6 P0006          FALSE                        9.9          45.6
# ℹ 5 more variables: participant_group <fct>, sleep_hours <dbl>,
#   social_hours <dbl>, wellbeing_index <dbl>, sleep_hours_round <dbl>

title: Practical
section: Exercise 7: Moderating Effect of In-Person Social Hours
text:
Exercise 7: Moderating Effect of In-Person Social Hours
Does in-person socialising buffer the effect of social media on wellbeing?
Let’s look at relationship between social_hours and wellbeing_index in participants who: (A) spend a lot of time socialising in-person, versus (B) spend relatively less time socialising in-person.
 Split in_person_hours into two groups: “high” (above the median) and “low” (below the median).

well_join <- well_join %>%
  mutate(in_person_band = case_when(
    in_person_hours > median(in_person_hours)   ~ "High",
    TRUE                  ~ "Low"
  )) %>%
  mutate(in_person_band = factor(in_person_band, levels = c("High", "Low")))

 Create scatterplots of social_hours versus wellbeing_index faceted by in_person_band.








 Do higher in‑person hours appear to buffer the relationship between social media use and wellbeing?

title: Practical
text:
Exercise 9: Correlation matrix
Select numeric variables and compute a correlation matrix.
Note: You may want to refer back to the code in the seminar for these steps.
 Create a new object called well_num by selecting just the numeric columns of well_join and removing the sleep_hours_round variable. Then use cor on well_num to compute correlations and round them to two digits.


Error in cor_mat[1:6, 1:6]: subscript out of bounds


 Tidy the matrix.


# A tibble: 6 × 3
  var1            var2                r
  <chr>           <chr>           <dbl>
1 in_person_hours in_person_hours  1   
2 in_person_hours wellbeing_90d    0.1 
3 in_person_hours sleep_hours      0.28
4 in_person_hours social_hours    -0.34
5 in_person_hours wellbeing_index  0.09
6 wellbeing_90d   in_person_hours  0.1 


 Plot cor_tidy using geom_tile(). Add a scale_fill_gradient2() line to customise the colors.








 Which variables are most strongly related to wellbeing_90d? To wellbeing_index? Do the relationships make sense?
You’re finished!

title: Week 4 Seminar: Barplots
text:
Why bars?

Heights of bars give us easy insights into categorical variables:


See counts / proportions of observations within each category

Displays patterns analyzed by Chi square

Summarise how a continuous variable differs across the categorical groups

Displays relationships analyzed by t-test, ANOVA, regression








intervention_id
participant_group
intervention_type
session_region
lead_clinician
symptom_reduction

19.4








We have categorical variables here like intervention type.
How many people in each intervention type group?
What are the proportion of people in each intervention type group?
How did symptom reduction (continuous) differ across intervention type groups?
So we can use heights of bars to show counts, proportions, and summary statistics.
We CAN calculate things like counts, proportions, and summary statistics ourselves e.g., using tidyverse, and then use them to specify the heights of bars.
But ggplot has ways of calculating things like counts proportions and summary statistics FOR US
So I’ll be showing both ways

title: Week 4 Seminar: Barplots
text:
Standard barplot of counts
default for geom_bar() is to plot counts

ggplot(mental_health, aes(x = session_region)) + #< y-axis specified by geom_bar()
  geom_bar() #< default stat = "count": counts number of ROWS per x-axis group


The default behavior for geom_bar is to count the number of values in each level of a variable, e.g., the number of patients in each region. There is a hidden default value for an argument in geom_bar() called “stat”, that indicates what kind of statistic should determine the height of the bar. By default the value is “count”, so tht it counts the frequency of each unique value in that variable, and that’s the height of the bar.

title: Week 4 Seminar: Barplots
text:
Standard barplot of counts
equivalent with wrangling

mental_health %>%
  count(session_region, name = "num_session") %>% #< calculate counts
  ggplot(aes(x = session_region, y = num_session)) + #< use counts as y-axis
  geom_bar(stat = "identity") #< override default


This is what’s happening under the hood - calculate counts then plot them. But if we count ourselves, we need to turn off the default stat = “count” and switch it to “identity” so it uses the y-axis variable

title: Week 4 Seminar: Barplots
text:
Standard barplot of counts
ordering levels of the variable

ggplot(mental_health, aes(x = fct_infreq(session_region))) + #< order bars by counts
  geom_bar() 


We can do a bit of wrangling so that our bars are ordered by these counts

title: Week 4 Seminar: Barplots
text:
Standard barplot of counts
equivalent with wrangling

mental_health %>%
  count(session_region, name = "num_session") %>% #< calculate counts
  ggplot(aes(x = reorder(session_region, num_session), y = num_session)) + #< reorder
  geom_bar(stat = "identity") #< override default


Again, note use of identity

title: Week 4 Seminar: Barplots
text:
Today




barplot of counts
barplot of proportions



barplot of summary stats
grouped barplot of summary stats

title: Week 4 Seminar: Barplots
text:
Barplot of proportions
difficult to compare across groups?


Going back to this plot - this gives us absolute counts. But we might be less interested in absolute totals, and more in the relative frequencies across groups. For this we need proportions.

title: Week 4 Seminar: Barplots
text:
Barplot of proportions
convert counts to proportions

ggplot(mental_health, aes(x = session_region)) +
  geom_bar(aes(fill = participant_group), position = "fill") + #< this switches to proportions
  scale_y_continuous(name = "prop") #< adjust the label from default "count"


Now we’re still counting up the numbers, but now before stacking, we calculate the proportion of each count from the total.

title: Week 4 Seminar: Barplots
text:
Barplot of proportions
wrangling equivalent

mental_health %>%
  count(session_region, participant_group, name = "num_session") %>% #< calculate counts
  group_by(session_region) %>% #< for each session_region...
  mutate(prop = num_session / sum(num_session)) %>% #< calculate proportion out of total count
  ungroup() %>%
  ggplot(aes(x = session_region, y = prop)) +
  geom_bar(aes(fill = participant_group), stat = "identity") #< identity

title: Week 4 Seminar: Barplots
text:
Barplots of proportions / counts

What if we had multiple records (rows) per patient, but we still wanted to plot the number of patients?
What would happen if we went straight to:

ggplot(mental_health, aes(x = session_region)) + #< y-axis specified by geom_bar()
  geom_bar() #< default stat = "count": counts number of ROWS per x-axis group


Think about need to wrangle before plotting

text:

barplot of counts
barplot of proportions



barplot of summary stats
grouped barplot of summary stats



This has all just been counting numbers of observations in categorical groups. Allows us to see how counts vary across groups, whether counts are similar, whether proportions are similar.
But tells us nothing about the relationship with other variables.

how does symptom_reduction vary across groups?


Standard approach is to calculate a summary statistic for central tendency - typically mean - of that continuous outcome variable for each categorical group
And add some indication of variability around that central tendency - typically standard error or confidence interval. Do people need a reminder of these?

Barplot of summary stats
simplified in comparison to distributions


See how it’s a summarized version of violin / boxplots we saw before

simplified in comparison to distributions


See how it’s a summarized version of violin / boxplots we saw before

title: Week 4 Seminar: Barplots
text:
Barplot of summary stats
handy stat_summary

mental_health %>%
  ggplot(aes(x = intervention_type, y = symptom_reduction)) +
  stat_summary(fun = "mean", geom = "bar") #< specify summary stat and shape

title: Week 4 Seminar: Barplots
text:
Barplot of summary stats
handy stat_summary

mental_health %>%
  ggplot(aes(x = intervention_type, y = symptom_reduction)) +
  stat_summary(fun = "mean", geom = "bar") +
  stat_summary(fun.data = "mean_se", geom = "linerange") #< add error bars

title: Week 4 Seminar: Barplots
text:
Barplot of summary stats
handy stat_summary

mental_health %>%
  ggplot(aes(x = intervention_type, y = symptom_reduction)) +
  stat_summary(aes(fill = intervention_type), fun = "mean", geom = "bar", show.legend = F) +
  stat_summary(fun.data = "mean_se", geom = "linerange") #< add error bars


Color the bars

title: Week 4 Seminar: Barplots
text:
Barplot of summary stats
equivalent with wrangling

mental_health %>%
  group_by(intervention_type) %>% #< for each intervention_type group...
  summarise(
    mean = mean(symptom_reduction, na.rm = TRUE), #< calculate mean
    se = sd(symptom_reduction, na.rm = TRUE) / sqrt(n()) #< calculate SE
  ) %>%
  ggplot(aes(x = intervention_type, y = mean)) + #< choose mean as y-axis
  geom_bar(aes(fill = intervention_type), stat = "identity", show.legend = F) + #< identity!
  geom_linerange(aes(ymin = mean - se, ymax = mean + se)) #< range of error bar

title: Week 4 Seminar: Barplots
text:
Summary: Bar Plots
What bars are good for:

Counts within categories
Proportions within a category
Summaries of a continuous outcome by category (mean/SE or CI)

title: Week 4 Seminar: Barplots
text:
Key mechanics

Counts: geom_bar() (default stat = “count”)
Pre-computed y: geom_bar(stat = “identity”)
Unstacked bars: position = “dodge”
Proportions: position = “fill” (stack to 100%)
Summary stats: stat_summary(fun = “…”, geom = “…”)
Unstacked errorbars: position_dodge(width = .9)

title: Week 4 Seminar: Barplots
text:
Upcoming

Relationships between variables with scatterplots

title: Overview
text:
This week you will learn how to use bar plots to visualise categorical data. We will cover counts, proportions, and summary statistics, as well as how to handle grouped bar plots.

Learning objectives
The successful student will be able to:

generate bar plots to show counts of categorical variables
create bar plots of proportions to compare relative frequencies
plot summary statistics (e.g., means and error bars) for continuous outcomes by group
produce grouped bar plots to compare multiple categorical variables simultaneously

Exercise 1: Histogram Practice
 Make a histogram of stress_score. Try two different bin settings and briefly note what changes.
Reflect: How does the bin size influence the level of fine detail you can see in the data?

title: Practical
text:
In this practical you will read in a dataset and plot distributions in various ways. You will also get a bit of practice with tidyverse data wrangling.

Practicals are not a test. It is expected that you often don’t know how to start, make a lot of mistakes and need help. It is expected that you are familiar with independent study content before the workshop. However, you need not remember or understand every detail as the workshop should build and consolidate your understanding. Tips

don’t worry about making mistakes
don’t let what you can not do interfere with what you can do
discussing code with your neighbours will help
look things up in the independent study material
look things up in your own code from earlier workshops
there are no stupid questions







Key



These four symbols are used at the beginning of each instruction so you know where to carry out the instruction.
 Something you need to do on your computer. It may be opening programs or documents or locating a file.
 Something you should do in RStudio. It will often be typing a command or using the menus but might also be creating folders, locating or moving files.
 Something you should do in your browser on the internet. It may be searching for information, going to the VLE or downloading a file.
 A question for you to think about and answer. Record your answers in your script for future reference.

title: Practical
text:
Wellbeing
We’ll be working with a simulated dataset is based on a fictional cross-sectional survey study exploring the relationships between social support, therapy attendance, loneliness, sleep quality, and overall wellbeing in adults.
In this fictional study, participants were recruited from community mental health clinics and general community advertisements between 2019 and 2022. They completed a survey assessing:

Perceived social support (categorized as Low, Medium, or High)
Current therapy status (Yes or No)
Loneliness (a standardized loneliness score; higher scores indicate greater loneliness)
Subjective wellbeing (higher scores indicate better wellbeing)
Sleep quality (rated on a 1–10 scale)
Demographics, including age and sex

The fictional study aimed to understand how social support and therapy might relate to feelings of loneliness and overall wellbeing, as well as how these factors interact with sleep and demographic characteristics.

title: Practical
text:
Packages
Remember that packages, such as ggplot2 (Wickham 2016) need to be installed once and then loaded each session. ggplot2 is one of the tidyverse (Wickham et al. 2019) packages.
Today, we’ll be using tidyverse and ggridges






Important



If you are working on a University computer (or the VDS) you do not need to install tidyverse.
If you are working on your own computer or using RStudio cloud you do need to install tidyverse.


To install a package:
 Go the Packages tab on the lower right pane. Click Install and type the name of the package into the box that appears.
Wait until you get the prompt back. It will take a few moments, be patient!
To use a package which is installed you have to load it with the library() function. You will need to do this whether you are working on your own computer or on a University computer
 Load the tidyverse and ggridges. Type or copy the following code into your R script:

library(tidyverse)
library(ggridges)

title: Practical
text:
Reading in data
You will go into more depth about reading in data in the Data Analysis module For now, you can just follow these steps.
 Save this file in your week-3 folder:

Data from fictional wellbeing study: therapy_data.csv


 Add the following code to your R script and run:

therapy_df <- read_csv("therapy_data.csv")

title: Practical
text:
Look at data
 Examine the variables and first few rows of the therapy_df object using head()

head(therapy_df)

# A tibble: 6 × 8
  support_level therapy   age loneliness_score wellbeing_score sleep_quality
  <chr>         <chr>   <dbl>            <dbl>           <dbl>         <dbl>
1 Medium        No         42             30.4            58.6             6
2 Low           Yes        23             72.2            44.5             6
3 Low           No         35             47.1            39.8             7
4 Medium        No         23             35.1            56.8             8
5 Medium        Yes        20             57.0            60.6             6
6 Medium        No         40             47.2            61.5             6
# ℹ 2 more variables: sex <chr>, year <dbl>


See that you have a table where each column is a variable from the fictional study, such as wellbeing_score. Each row contains values for each variable for one participant.

title: Practical
text:
Exercise 1: Histograms
Look at the distribution of the loneliness_score variable.
 Plot the distribution by creating a plot in which the x-axis variable is loneliness_score and the distribution of this variable is shown as a histogram.








 Try different numbers of bins (e.g., 10, 30, 50)
 Look up the named colors
 Choose a color from the list and use it to change the fill color of your histogram

title: Practical
text:
Exercise 2: Comparing distributions in groups
A density plot allows us to look at the overall shape of the distribution, rather than counts of values within bins.
 Create a density plot of loneliness_score.

ggplot(therapy_df, aes(x = loneliness_score)) +
  geom_density()







We can examine both the histogram and density plot by overlaying them.
 Overlay density and histogram of loneliness_score.

ggplot(therapy_df, aes(x = loneliness_score, y = after_stat(density))) +
  geom_histogram(binwidth = 5, fill = "blue", 
                 color = "black", alpha = 0.5) +
  geom_density()







What if we want to examine how loneliness_score varies across groups, such as people with different levels of support (in the support_level variable)? One way we can look at this is to overlay the density of loneliness_score for each support_level.
To do this, we can copy the density plot from the first part of this exercise, but within the brackets for geom_density(), use support_level to control the fill aesthetic.
 Copy your code for plotting loneliness_score density, and add some aes() code within the geom_density() to fill based on support_level.








See that the fill is opaque, so the densities cover each other up. We can make them transparent by setting alpha to a value lower than 1, as we did in the histogram above.
 Set the alpha level for geom_density() to 0.5.

title: Practical
text:
Exercise 3: Boxplots
Our last density plot allowed us to get a sense of how the distributions of loneliness_score varied for different levels of support (support_level). But, we might find that visual a bit crowded. Perhaps we want to get a more compact depiction of the distributions and visually separate distributions for each support_level. One way to do this is to use boxplots.
 Create this basic boxplot

ggplot(therapy_df, aes(x = support_level, y = loneliness_score)) +
  geom_boxplot()







What if we want to keep the compact format of the boxplot, but also see the distribution of individual points?
 Add a geom_jitter() line to show individual observations








 This is a little busy! Set alpha for geom_jitter() to below 1, e.g., 0.2.








Boxplots show medians and quartiles. We can plot additional summary statistics, like mean values, using stat_summary()
 Copy the code below to add a point indicating the mean value, and edit the content within stat_summary() to change the color of the points.

ggplot(therapy_df, aes(x = support_level, y = loneliness_score)) +
  geom_boxplot() +
  stat_summary(fun = mean, geom = "point")

title: Practical
text:
Exercise 4: Violin plots
The boxplots we just generated were less crowded than the overlapping density plots. However, this advantage came at a cost: we can no longer see the shape of the distribution. A violin plot allows us to compare the shape of the distribution for one variable across levels of another variable.
 Generate this basic violin plot

ggplot(therapy_df, aes(x = support_level, y = loneliness_score)) +
  geom_violin()







If we want to combine the advantages of a boxplot (compact depiction of medians and quartiles) with the advantages of a violinplot (showing the shapes of the distributions), we can overlay them.
 Overlay a violin and boxplot

ggplot(therapy_df, aes(x = support_level, y = loneliness_score)) + 
  geom_violin() +
  geom_boxplot()







Hm, these boxplots are very big and cover up parts of the violin plots underneath!
 Within geom_boxplot(), change the width to something narrower, like 0.1








 To help us visually compare the distributions, within geom_violin(), use support_level to control the fill aesthetic

title: Practical
text:
Exercise 5: Ridgeline plots
You might have noticed that each “violin” in a violin plot essentially shows the distribution twice (the two “sides” of the violin). Ridgeline plots allow you to show each distribution once in a nice visually separated way.
 Generate a basic ridgeline plot

ggplot(therapy_df, aes(x = loneliness_score, y = support_level)) +
  geom_density_ridges()







 Use support_level to control the fill aesthetic of geom_density_ridges() and set the overall alpha level to less than 1 (e.g., 0.5)

title: Practical
text:
Exercise 6: Wrangling practice with visualization
Currently, our dataset contains a lot of information. But we may want to go beyond the exact data in the dataset.
For example, we might want to look at differences in wellbeing for people who are low versus high in loneliness. We can’t do this with the data as-is because loneliness_score is a continuous variable.
This poses an extremely common data wrangling issue: we need to use the data we have to derive some new values of interest.
 Use mutate and ifelse to create a new variable called loneliness_level in which loneliness_scrores above the median value are high and those at or below median are low.

# This code generates the new variable
therapy_df <- therapy_df %>%
  mutate(loneliness_level = ifelse(loneliness_score > median(loneliness_score), "high", "low"))

# We can see that this new variable is added to therapy_df
head(therapy_df)

# A tibble: 6 × 9
  support_level therapy   age loneliness_score wellbeing_score sleep_quality
  <chr>         <chr>   <dbl>            <dbl>           <dbl>         <dbl>
1 Medium        No         42             30.4            58.6             6
2 Low           Yes        23             72.2            44.5             6
3 Low           No         35             47.1            39.8             7
4 Medium        No         23             35.1            56.8             8
5 Medium        Yes        20             57.0            60.6             6
6 Medium        No         40             47.2            61.5             6
# ℹ 3 more variables: sex <chr>, year <dbl>, loneliness_level <chr>


 Use either a boxplot, violin plot, or ridge plot to depict the distribution of wellbeing_score for each loneliness_level: your choice!
You’re finished!

title: Independent Study to Prepare
text:
Preparation for Weeks 2 and 3: Get Acquainted with Tidy Data Wrangling
This preparation involves reading some chapters in an online book and getting started with an online DataCamp course. I will recommend this preparation for weeks 2 and 3. You can try taking an initial look in week 2, and revisit the reading more deeply in week 3.
Although the focus of this module is on data visualisation, before you visualise data, you often need to take some steps to get it into a form that you can visualise. These steps are often referred to using phrases like “data management” and “data wrangling”. These days, it is common practice in R to perform steps to ensure that your data are in a standard, “tidy” format in which data are stored in a table where each row is an observation and each column is a variable. Common steps for preparing data for visualisation and analysis include:

Generating summary statistics, such as the mean value of an outcome variable for groups of participants
Selecting a subset of data, such as a subset of variables, or rows for just participants in a subset of groups

The Data Analysis module that you will be completing at the same time will cover many common tidy data wrangling steps, particularly in Weeks 3 and 4. Therefore, we won’t spend much time covering these steps in the seminars for Data Visualisation. However, since this is a crucial part of working with data in R, you will benefit from getting acquainted with it for this module as well.
There are many resources for learning about tidy data wrangling. You are encouraged to try the following two resources:

Read Tidyverse Ch 4 - 7

Introduction to the Tidyverse

title: Week 2 Seminar: Grammar of Graphics

Packages

To expand R’s capabilities, we often need to use packages
The main package we’ll be using to generate graphics is ggplot2

install.packages("ggplot2")
library(ggplot2)

title: Week 2 Seminar: Grammar of Graphics
text:
ggplot


What is the grammar of graphics?
A framework for building plots by combining basic building blocks, e.g.,:

geometric objects (like points or bars)
data
visual mappings (like position and color)

in a consistent, structured way

title: Week 2 Seminar: Grammar of Graphics
text:
ggplot


A graphic…


maps variables in the data +
to the aesthetic attributes +
of geometric objects +



with possible …



statistical transformations +
different coordinate systems +
and faceting

title: Week 2 Seminar: Grammar of Graphics
section: How do we “map” data to a graphic?
text:
How do we “map” data to a graphic?


The way we depict variables in our data as axes, bars, points, etc. dictates the way that patterns such as comparisons and changes are perceived
A non-exhaustive list:

length
color (or saturation)
position
size
shape
area
angle

title: Week 2 Seminar: Grammar of Graphics
text:
ggplot


Bulding blocks


data
aesthetics: specify variables to use for axes, shapes
geom: the shapes that will depict the data
scales: customise how variables are used to depict axes, shapes
statistical transformations: depict summaries (e.g., means) and model fits
coord: customise axis ranges and appearance
theme: customise features such as font size, background color, legend position
facets: break graphic into subsets

data
aesthetics: specify variables to use for axes, shapes

title: Week 2 Seminar: Grammar of Graphics
text:
ggplot

ggplot(data = psych_df, aes(x = stress_score))



We can choose a variable to plot

title: Week 2 Seminar: Grammar of Graphics
text:
ggplot

ggplot(data = psych_df, aes(x = stress_score)) +
  geom_histogram()


But we need to tell ggplot what GEOMETRY to use to visualize that variable. Here, a histogram

title: Week 2 Seminar: Grammar of Graphics
text:
ggplot

ggplot(data = psych_df, aes(x = diagnosis, y = stress_score)) +
  geom_boxplot()


Now, what if we wanted to keep looking at that distribution of stress, but break it down by diagnosis? Here, we need to add that diagnosis variable as an axis and choose a geometry to depict it. We’ll try boxplot.

title: Week 2 Seminar: Grammar of Graphics
text:
ggplot

ggplot(data = psych_df, aes(x = diagnosis, y = stress_score)) +
  geom_violin()



Or violin plot

title: Week 2 Seminar: Grammar of Graphics
text:
ggplot

psych_df %>%
  group_by(diagnosis) %>%
  summarize(stress_score_mean = mean(stress_score)) %>%
  ggplot(aes(x = diagnosis, y = stress_score_mean)) +
  geom_bar(stat = "identity")


What if we don’t want to look at the full distribution - we just want to look at the average tendencies for each diagnosis? Well here we want a bar plot. But we need to calculate that average tendency somehow.
One way to do that would be to use the data to calculate the averages first, and then plot them.

title: Week 2 Seminar: Grammar of Graphics
text:
ggplot

psych_df %>%
  ggplot(aes(x = sleep_hours, y = stress_score)) +
  geom_point()


Suppose we want to see, beyond diagnosis, are there variables associated with stress? How about sleep? Now we’re looking at a relationship between continuous variables, so the appropriate choice here is a scatterplot. So the geeometry we’ll use is points in a scatterplot.

title: Week 2 Seminar: Grammar of Graphics
text:
ggplot

psych_df %>%
  ggplot(aes(x = sleep_hours, y = stress_score)) +
  geom_point(aes(color = diagnosis))


What if we want to incorporate another variable into this plot. E.g., what if we want to visualize stress, sleep AND diagnosis? We can control another aesthetic using the diagnosis variable - e.g., point color

title: Week 2 Seminar: Grammar of Graphics
text:
ggplot

psych_df %>%
  ggplot(aes(x = sleep_hours, y = stress_score)) +
  geom_point(aes(shape = diagnosis))


We could use diagnosis to control another aesthetic, like shape

title: Week 2 Seminar: Grammar of Graphics
text:
ggplot

psych_df %>%
  ggplot(aes(x = stress_score, y = diagnosis)) +
  geom_point(aes(color = sleep_hours))


We could change the way we map our variables to aesthetics - axes, shapes

data

text:
ggplot

psych_df %>%
  ggplot(aes(x = sleep_hours, y = stress_score)) +
  geom_point()


Customize how the variables are plotted as points

title: Week 2 Seminar: Grammar of Graphics
text:
ggplot

psych_df %>%
  ggplot(aes(x = sleep_hours, y = stress_score)) +
  geom_point(color = "blue", size = 2)


Customize how the variables are plotted as points

title: Week 2 Seminar: Grammar of Graphics
text:
ggplot

psych_df %>%
  ggplot(aes(x = sleep_hours, y = stress_score)) +
  geom_point(aes(color = diagnosis), size = 2)


Use another variable to control the color

title: Week 2 Seminar: Grammar of Graphics
text:
ggplot

psych_df %>%
  ggplot(aes(x = sleep_hours, y = stress_score)) +
  geom_point(aes(color = diagnosis), size = 2) +
  scale_color_manual(values = c("darkgray", "deeppink", "blue")) +
  scale_x_continuous(name = "Sleep in Hours", 
                     breaks = seq(0, 12, by = 2), limits = c(0, 12))


Use another variable to control the color and customise

  summarize(stress_score_mean = mean(stress_score)) %>%
  ggplot(aes(x = diagnosis, y = stress_score_mean)) +
  geom_bar(stat = "identity")


What if we want to change how the axes are depicted?

title: Week 2 Seminar: Grammar of Graphics
text:
ggplot

psych_df %>%
  group_by(diagnosis) %>%
  summarize(stress_score_mean = mean(stress_score)) %>%
  ggplot(aes(x = diagnosis, y = stress_score_mean)) +
  geom_bar(stat = "identity") +
  coord_cartesian(ylim = c(10, 40))

title: Week 2 Seminar: Grammar of Graphics
text:
ggplot

psych_df %>%
  group_by(diagnosis) %>%
  summarize(stress_score_mean = mean(stress_score)) %>%
  ggplot(aes(x = diagnosis, y = stress_score_mean)) +
  geom_bar(stat = "identity") +
  coord_flip()


Change the orientation

title: Week 2 Seminar: Grammar of Graphics
text:
ggplot


Bulding blocks

data
aesthetics: specify variables to use for axes, shapes
geom: the shapes that will depict the data
scales: customise how variables are used to depict axes, shapes
statistical transformations: depict summaries (e.g., means) and model fits
coord: customise axis ranges and appearance
theme: customise features such as font size, background color, legend position
facets: break graphic into subsets

title: Week 2 Seminar: Grammar of Graphics
text:
ggplot

psych_df %>%
  ggplot(aes(x = sleep_hours, y = stress_score)) +
  geom_point(aes(color = diagnosis), size = 2) +
  scale_color_manual(values = c("darkgray", "deeppink", "blue")) +
  scale_x_continuous(name = "Sleep in Hours", 
                     breaks = seq(0, 12, by = 2), limits = c(0, 12)) 


We often want to control the other aspects of appearance, such as font size

title: Week 2 Seminar: Grammar of Graphics
text:
ggplot

psych_df %>%
  ggplot(aes(x = sleep_hours, y = stress_score)) +
  geom_point(aes(color = diagnosis), size = 2) +
  scale_color_manual(values = c("darkgray", "deeppink", "blue")) +
  scale_x_continuous(name = "Sleep in Hours", 
                     breaks = seq(0, 12, by = 2), limits = c(0, 12)) +
  theme(legend.position = "top",
        legend.title = element_blank(),
        panel.grid = element_blank())


We can add a theme() code and specify the appearance of various characteristics

title: Week 2 Seminar: Grammar of Graphics
text:
ggplot

psych_df %>%
  ggplot(aes(x = sleep_hours, y = stress_score)) +
  geom_point(aes(color = diagnosis), size = 2) +
  scale_color_manual(values = c("darkgray", "deeppink", "blue")) +
  scale_x_continuous(name = "Sleep in Hours", 
                     breaks = seq(0, 12, by = 2), limits = c(0, 12)) +
  theme_bw()


There are also built-in themes that control many characteristics at once

title: Week 2 Seminar: Grammar of Graphics
text:
ggplot


Bulding blocks

data
aesthetics: specify variables to use for axes, shapes
geom: the shapes that will depict the data
scales: customise how variables are used to depict axes, shapes
statistical transformations: depict summaries (e.g., means) and model fits
coord: customise axis ranges and appearance
theme: customise features such as font size, background color, legend position
facets: break graphic into subsets



Facets are especially handy when we have some pattern of relationships between some variables, and we want to see how that pattern VARIES ACROSS DIFFERENT GROUPS.

title: Week 2 Seminar: Grammar of Graphics
text:
ggplot

psych_df %>%
  ggplot(aes(x = sex, y = stress_score)) +
  geom_point(position = position_jitter(width = .1))


What if we want to see how this relationship varies across another variable? Like different diagnoses? Too much to combine into a single plot

title: Week 2 Seminar: Grammar of Graphics
text:
ggplot

psych_df %>%
  ggplot(aes(x = sex, y = stress_score)) +
  facet_wrap(~diagnosis) +
  geom_point(position = position_jitter(width = .1))


Instead, break across facets

title: Week 2 Seminar: Grammar of Graphics
text:
Summary: Grammar of Graphics

Minimum for plot = data + aes() + geom()
Map variables to aesthetics: x, y, color/fill, shape, size, alpha, linetype.
Pick geoms to match the question: hist/box/violin (distributions), bar (summaries/counts), point (relationships).
Use stats when needed: stat_summary() for means/SE; stat=“identity” when you’ve already computed values.
Tune scales & labels: scale_*_*(), labs().
Adjust axes/orientation: coord_cartesian(), coord_flip(), coord_polar().
Polish appearance: theme(), built-ins (theme_bw())
Compare subsets with facets: facet_wrap() / facet_grid().

title: Week 2 Seminar: Grammar of Graphics
text:
Workflow checklist

Start with a clear question.
Choose mappings (what goes to x/y/color/…?).
Select geom (how should it look?).
Add stat/facet if it clarifies the story.
Refine with scales/coord; label units.
Finish with theme
Check clarity & integrity

title: Overview
text:
This week you will get an introduction to the standard approach to creating visualisations in R. There is a preparation step to get acquainted with standard data management in R.

Learning objectives
The successful student will be able to:

generate common types of graphs, including histograms, barplots, and scatterplots
customise the way variables are used to generate the axes and contents of the graph
customise the appearance of graphs, including colors and axis ranges

title: Independent Study to consolidate this week
text: There is no additional study this week - instead, go ahead and check out Prepare! for next week.

title: Practical
text: There is no practical this week.

title: Data Visualisation
text:
This module introduces you to data visualisation in R.


The Module Learning outcomes are:

Explore and understand datasets by visualising distributions, relationships, and trends.
Design clear and comprehensible visualisations that avoid common pitfalls.
Communicate findings to diverse audiences through compelling storytelling.
Build interactive dashboards that combine multiple visualisations.
Apply these skills across your degree and in a wide range of careers.

title: Data Visualisation
text:

title: Data Visualisation
text:
Week 1: Principles of Data Visualisation
This week you will read a short paper about what makes a good visualization, and we will discuss this topic further in the seminar. There will be no practical.

title: Data Visualisation
text:
Week 2: Grammar of Graphics
This week you will be introduced to the fundamental tool for building visualizations in R: the grammar of graphics. We will discuss elements of the grammar of graphics in the seminar, and you will practice using it in the practical. In preparation for this week, you will start working through lessons on DataCamp on wrangling data in R using the tidyverse.

title: Data Visualisation
text:
Week 3: Distributions
This week, we will dive into how to plot the shape and range of variables in data. We will discuss common plots including histograms, density plots, boxplots and violin plots, and you will gain practice creating these graphs in the practical. You will also continue working through tidyverse lessons on DataCamp.

title: Data Visualisation
section: Week 4: Bar Plots for Categorical Data
text:
Week 4: Bar Plots for Categorical Data
This week, we will explore bar plots as a key tool for plotting characteristics of categorical data. We will discuss how to use bar plots to depict counts, proportions and summary statistics, and you will gain practice using bar plots in the practical.

title: Data Visualisation
text:
Week 5: Relationships between Variables
This week, we will examine relationships between variables. We will do a deep dive into scatterplots, adding trend lines, depicting how relationships differ across categorical groups, and correlation matrices. The practical will walk you through building these plots. To prepare for the following week, you will complete lessons on working with date and time variables on DataCamp.

title: Data Visualisation
section: Week 6: Time Series and Line Graphs
text:
Week 6: Time Series and Line Graphs
This week, we will explore how to visualise changes over time using line graphs. We will discuss how to de-clutter and emphasize temporal trends and work with date and time variables in the seminar, and you will practice depicting temporal data in the practical.

title: Data Visualisation
text:
Week 7: Advanced Customisation
Thus far, we have been exploring the different types of plots that can be used to illustrate different types of patterns. This week, we will transition customising the appearance of our plots for clarity and appeal. We will highlight several tools for improving plots including: customising and adding explanatory labels and annotations, formatting axes with appropriate breaks, effective use of color, reducing visual clutter, and combining multiple plots for comparison and synthesis.

title: Week 1 Seminar: Principles of Data Visualisation
text:
Module organization

Explore
Explain


To accomplish these objectives, the module will be roughly divided into two parts.
In the first several weeks, we’ll discuss using visualizations to EXPLORE data.
So we’ll go through the main types of graph you can use to get a sense of the patterns in your data. So the focus here will be more on giving you tools to understand the data for yourself.
Then once you have a toolkit with lots of different kinds of graph, we’ll shift the focus to EXPLAINING data. So we’ll be seeing how to adapt the tools you’ve learned to make the patterns clear and compelling to an audience.

title: Week 1 Seminar: Principles of Data Visualisation
text:
Why visualise data?


Turn to a visual, and you immediately start seeing more.
This is something called a violin plot, with points added for individual data points [EXPLAIN]
This gives you both the sense that maybe the two groups differ, like the summary statistics.
BUT ALSO we can see outliers.

title: Week 1 Seminar: Principles of Data Visualisation
text:
Why visualise data?


We can enhance this further by adding lines to see trends in change over time, from pre to post.
Now we can see that in this main group of participants, symptom severity mostly goes down over time.
But those outliers are outliers not just in severity, but in lack of change.
And we can enhance this graph even further to get a sense of WHY those points are outliers.

title: Week 1 Seminar: Principles of Data Visualisation
text:
Why visualise data?


So here I’ve colored the points by the person who assessed the patients. And we can see that the outliers were all assessed by the same person.
Based on personal example.

title: Week 1 Seminar: Principles of Data Visualisation
text:
Why visualise data?


Finally, now that our exploration with visuals has revealed these outliers, we can do something about it.
We can regraph the data without the outliers. And now a clear trend pops out.

To explore: find patterns, outliers, structure
To diagnose: check assumptions, spot problems

title: Practical
text:
In this introduction you will start working with RStudio. You will read in a dataset and plot the data it contains in various ways.

Practicals are not a test. It is expected that you often don’t know how to start, make a lot of mistakes and need help. It is expected that you are familiar with independent study content before the workshop. However, you need not remember or understand every detail as the workshop should build and consolidate your understanding. Tips

don’t worry about making mistakes
don’t let what you can not do interfere with what you can do
discussing code with your neighbours will help
look things up in the independent study material
look things up in your own code from earlier workshops
there are no stupid questions







Key



These four symbols are used at the beginning of each instruction so you know where to carry out the instruction.
 Something you need to do on your computer. It may be opening programs or documents or locating a file.
 Something you should do in RStudio. It will often be typing a command or using the menus but might also be creating folders, locating or moving files.
 Something you should do in your browser on the internet. It may be searching for information, going to the VLE or downloading a file.
 A question for you to think about and answer. Record your answers in your script for future reference.

title: Practical
text:
Wellbeing
We’ll be working with a simulated dataset is based on a fictional cross-sectional survey study exploring the relationships between social support, therapy attendance, loneliness, sleep quality, and overall wellbeing in adults.
In this fictional study, participants were recruited from community mental health clinics and general community advertisements between 2019 and 2022. They completed a survey assessing:

Perceived social support (categorized as Low, Medium, or High)
Current therapy status (Yes or No)
Loneliness (a standardized loneliness score; higher scores indicate greater loneliness)
Subjective wellbeing (higher scores indicate better wellbeing)
Sleep quality (rated on a 1–10 scale)
Demographics, including age and sex

The fictional study aimed to understand how social support and therapy might relate to feelings of loneliness and overall wellbeing, as well as how these factors interact with sleep and demographic characteristics.

title: Practical
text:
Packages
Commands like c(), sum(), and str() are in packages which are part the ‘base’ R system. A package is a collection of related commands. Base packages are installed automatically when you install R.
Other packages, such as ggplot2 (Wickham 2016) need to be installed once and then loaded each session. ggplot2 is one of the tidyverse (Wickham et al. 2019) packages.






Important



If you are working on a University computer (or the VDS) you do not need to install tidyverse.
If you are working on your own computer or using RStudio cloud you do need to install tidyverse.


To install a package:
 Go the Packages tab on the lower right pane. Click Install and type tidyverse into the box that appears.
Wait until you get the prompt back. It will take a few moments, be patient!
To use a package which is installed you have to load it with the library() function. You will need to do this whether you are working on your own computer or on a University computer
 Load the tidyverse. Type or copy the following code into your R script:

library(tidyverse)

 Ensure your cursor is on the line with the code you just added and hit Ctrl+Enter to run it.
You can follow this same step to run any code you add to your R script!
You will likely be warned of some function name conflicts but these will not be a problem for you.

title: Practical
text:
Reading in data
You will go into more depth about reading in data in the Data Analysis module. For now, you can just follow these steps.
 Save this file in your week-2 folder:

Data from fictional wellbeing study: therapy_data.csv


 Add the following code to your R script and run:

therapy_df <- read_csv("therapy_data.csv")

title: Practical
text:
Look at data
 Examine the variables and first few rows of the therapy_df object using head()

head(therapy_df)

# A tibble: 6 × 8
  support_level therapy   age loneliness_score wellbeing_score sleep_quality
  <chr>         <chr>   <dbl>            <dbl>           <dbl>         <dbl>
1 Medium        No         42             30.4            58.6             6
2 Low           Yes        23             72.2            44.5             6
3 Low           No         35             47.1            39.8             7
4 Medium        No         23             35.1            56.8             8
5 Medium        Yes        20             57.0            60.6             6
6 Medium        No         40             47.2            61.5             6
# ℹ 2 more variables: sex <chr>, year <dbl>


See that you have a table where each column is a variable from the fictional study, such as wellbeing_score. Each row contains values for each variable for one participant.

title: Practical
text:
Exercise 1: Distributions
Look at the distribution of the main outcome variable, the wellbeing score.
 Plot the distribution by creating a plot in which the x-axis variable is wellbeing_score and the distribution of this variable is shown as a histogram.

ggplot(therapy_df, aes(x = wellbeing_score)) +
  geom_histogram()







Any geom has multiple attributes, such as color. When you just specify the geom followed by empty brackets, like geom_histogram(), the values for those attributes are chosen by default. This means that, under the hood, geom_histogram() is setting the fill of the bars to a gray color, like this:

ggplot(therapy_df, aes(x = wellbeing_score)) +
  geom_histogram(fill = "#525252")







Similarly, geom_histogram() chooses the number “bins” that group together values within the same bar.
For this dataset, the default is 30 bins. So the code above is the same as the code below and produces the same histogram:

ggplot(therapy_df, aes(x = wellbeing_score)) +
  geom_histogram(bins = 30)







But, we can change these defaults.
 Try setting the bins to a larger or smaller number than 30 and see what happens.

title: Practical
text:
Exercise 2: Comparing distributions in groups
What if we want to see the distribution of wellbeing_score for different groups of people, such as people with different levels of support? We can do this using a boxplot.
 Create a boxplot:

ggplot(therapy_df, aes(x = support_level, y = wellbeing_score)) +
  geom_boxplot()







Just like geom_histogram(), geom_boxplot() is actually setting values for attributes like fill to a default value. As you can see, the boxes are filled in white.
 Try changing the fill to a different color, like “red”.
See Exercise 1 above for an example of setting the fill color to a value (above the color was a hex string: “#525252”, but here you can change it to the name of a common color, like “red” )
 Change the fill color
Now, instead of setting all boxes to the same color, we can use a variable to control the fill aesthetic.
 Try using the support_level variable to control the fill aesthetic.
You will still modify the content inside the brackets for geom_boxplot(), but now instead of fill = "color_name", you’ll need to use aes(fill = name_of_variable).
 Once you’ve used the suport_level variable to control the fill aesthetic, you can add a line to choose specific fill colors for each support_level. Copy your code above, add a + at the end of the last line, and add this line:

scale_fill_manual(values = c("red", "blue", "purple"))

 Try a violin plot instead using geom_violin(). what differences do you see?

title: Practical
section: Exercise 3: Visualising summaries with bar plots
text:
Exercise 3: Visualising summaries with bar plots
Instead of looking at the whole distribution of wellbeing_scores for each support level, maybe we just want to look at a summary statistic, like the mean values.
We can generate a new dataset that contains just mean values of wellbeing_scores for each support_level.
 Run the following code to generate the new summary dataset:

therapy_summary <- therapy_df %>%
  group_by(support_level) %>%
  summarise(wellbeing_score_mean = mean(wellbeing_score))

Use the therapy_summary data to create a barplot that depicts the mean wellbeing scores (on the y-axis) for each support level (x-axis) using geom_bar().
 Remember that within the brackets for geom_bar(), you need to specify stat = "identity" so that it uses the y-axis variable you specified.
 Change the bar colors to custom colors you choose using scale_fill_manual()
Check the seminar slides for examples of using manual scales!

title: Practical
text:
Exercise 4: Relationships between continuous variables
What if we want to look at relationships between continuous variables, such as loneliness_score and wellbeing_score?
 We can create a scatterplot, like this:

ggplot(therapy_df, aes(x = loneliness_score, y = wellbeing_score)) +
  geom_point()







 Modify the code above to use the support_level variable to control the color and shape aesthetics of geom_point()

title: Practical
text:
Exercise 5: Coordinate system adjustments
 Take the bar plot from Exercise 3 and flip the coordinates to horizontal bars using coord_flip()
 Try using coord_cartesian() to limit the y-axis range to focus on a particular range (e.g., ylim = c(40, 80))

title: Practical
text:
Exercise 7: Faceting
 Copy the same scatterplot of loneliness_score vs wellbeing_score from Exercise 4

ggplot(therapy_df, aes(x = loneliness_score, y = wellbeing_score)) +
  geom_point()







 Add a facet_wrap() line to create separate facets for each value of the support_level variable

ggplot(therapy_df, aes(x = loneliness_score, y = wellbeing_score)) +
  geom_point() +
  facet_wrap(~ support_level)







You’re finished!

title: Overview
text:
This week you will get a brief review of data management in R, then an in-depth walkthrough of the many ways to visualise distributions. There is a preparation step to get acquainted with standard data management in R.

Learning objectives
The successful student will be able to:

generate various types of plot to visualise distributions
overlay multiple plots to provide more visual information about distributions
customise the appearance of distribution plots (e.g., colors)
perform some basic data wrangling to prepare data for visualisation

mapping data variables to axes, shapes (bars, points, etc)
controlling attributes such as color, coordinate ranges
customising appearance
faceting

Distributions show the overall shape and spread of data that single summary statistics (like the mean) can miss



Help spot skew and outliers, which inform choices of appropriate analyses
